Introduction

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a common condition that affects most men as they age.  It is characterized by enlargement of the prostate gland with progressive urinary obstruction.  Treatment includes both pharmacologic and surgical options.

Pathophysiology



BPH is related to hormonal changes that occur as men age.  Circulating testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), the more active form, by 5-alpha reductase in prostatic stromal cells.  Binding of DHT to prostatic androgen receptors leads to increased production of fibroblast growth factor, transforming growth factor-beta, and, likely, other growth factors, which stimulate proliferation and decrease apoptosis in prostatic tissue.



In BPH, stromal and glandular hyperplasia in the periurethral (transition) zone can impinge on the urethra, leading to impaired voiding and incomplete bladder emptying (

figure 1
).  Microscopic or gross hematuria can sometimes arise due to the formation of new, friable suburothelial blood vessels.



From a therapeutic perspective, the pathophysiologic abnormalities in BPH can be considered with respect to both static and dynamic obstructive factors:



  • Static obstruction is due to persistent compression of the urethra by hyperplastic glandular tissue.
  • Dynamic obstruction is due to increased prostatic smooth muscle tone and loss of elasticity in the prostatic urethra.

Risk factors



  • Age:  Half of men show histologic prostatic hyperplasia by age 50, and symptoms are present in a majority of men age >60.  The incidence increases linearly with age.
  • Family history:  Men with a family history of BPH are at increased risk.
  • Race:  Black men are at higher risk than white men.
  • Lifestyle factors:  Obesity, sedentary lifestyle, and excessive alcohol and caffeine intake are associated with increased risk.
  • Hormone levels:  Although the pathophysiology of BPH is driven by DHT, hormone levels correlate poorly with risk for symptoms over time.

Pathology



BPH is characterized by nodular hyperplasia of prostatic tissue, primarily in the periurethral zone (

image 1
).  BPH is often mistakenly termed "benign prostatic hypertrophy," but histologic findings include an increase primarily in cell number (hyperplasia) instead of size (hypertrophy).



Initially, stromal cells are predominantly affected (grossly appearing as firm, gray nodules), but proliferation of epithelial elements (grossly appearing as soft, yellowish nodules) also occurs as the condition progresses.  In long-standing obstruction, hypertrophy of bladder smooth muscle may occur and is visible as prominent trabeculation in the bladder wall.

Clinical presentation



BPH typically presents with chronic symptoms related to impaired voiding.  As obstruction progresses, patients can experience incomplete bladder emptying, leading to more frequent and irritative voiding symptoms.  Typical symptoms include the following (

figure 2
):



  • Voiding (obstructive) symptoms:

    • Weak or intermittent stream with prolonged voiding time
    • Urinary hesitancy and straining (or inability) to void
    • Dribbling at the end of the void and incomplete emptying
  • Storage (irritative) symptoms:
    • Frequency
    • Urgency
    • Nocturia
    • Overflow incontinence

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of BPH is typically based on the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings.  A digital rectal examination (DRE) is indicated in the initial encounter; typical findings are as follows:



  • Smooth, firm, symmetric, nontender enlargement of the prostate suggests BPH.  Nodular pathologic changes in BPH predominantly affect the periurethral prostate zone, which is not directly accessible to DRE.
  • Prominent nodules/irregular surface, asymmetry, fluctuance/bogginess, or significant tenderness may indicate an alternate cause of prostate enlargement (eg, prostatitis, adenocarcinoma).

Laboratory evaluation and imaging



Diagnostic testing in BPH is oriented primarily to identifying complications and aggravating factors (eg, infection), ruling out serious conditions (eg, prostate adenocarcinoma), and guiding recommendations for surgical intervention (

figure 3
).  Not all tests are needed for most patients.  Useful studies include the following:



  • Urinalysis should be performed in most or all patients to rule out urinary tract infection, significant hematuria, and glucosuria (which can also cause nocturia and urinary frequency).
  • Serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA):  Controversial for screening in completely asymptomatic patients, PSA can predict the likelihood of prostate cancer in men evaluated for BPH.  BPH is associated with normal or mildly elevated PSA with a slow rise over time; prostate cancer can cause a very high PSA (eg, >10 ng/mL) with a rapid rise over time (ie, high PSA velocity).  PSA levels normally rise with age, so age-adjusted norms should be used in interpretation.
  • Serum creatinine:  Not needed for all patients, serum creatinine can be used to assess possible chronic kidney disease or acute kidney injury.
  • Postvoid residual urine assesses the amount of urine remaining in the bladder after urination.  It can be estimated using ultrasonography or measured directly with catheterization of the bladder.
  • Uroflowmetry measures the rate of urine flow.
  • Ultrasonography visualizes the prostate gland and measures its size.

Differential diagnosis



  • Infectious (bacterial) prostatitis:  Acute prostatitis often occurs in younger (eg, age <40) men and presents with fever, pelvic pain, pyuria, and a severely tender prostate.  Chronic bacterial prostatitis presents with recurrent episodes of dysuria and frequency with bacteriuria; fever and prostate tenderness are mild to absent.
  • Chronic (noninfectious) prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome:  This poorly understood disorder manifests with chronic-episodic pelvic pain, sometimes with obstructive voiding symptoms.  The incidence is highest in men in their 40s and decreases thereafter.
  • Urinary tract infection (UTI):  UTI can cause symptoms similar to those of BPH but is usually acute and associated with pain, burning during urination, and possible fever.
  • Neurogenic bladder:  This condition is caused by damage to the nerves that control the bladder.  It can lead to urinary incontinence or retention.
  • Prostate cancer (

    ):  Prostate cancer can cause symptoms similar to those of BPH but is usually associated with a hard, irregular prostate gland on DRE.
  • Urethral stricture:  A urethral stricture is narrowing of the urethra that can cause urinary obstruction.  Causes include prior infection, urethral trauma, malignancy, and history of urinary catheter placement.
  • Bladder stones:  Bladder stones can cause intermittent urinary obstruction and pain.
  • Glucosuria:  Glucosuria is seen in uncontrolled (or undiagnosed) diabetes mellitus.  It presents with polydipsia and polyuria.  The total daily volume of urine is increased in glucosuria, in contrast to BPH, which presents with frequent small voids.

Management



Management of BPH depends on the severity of the symptoms and associated complications (eg, recurrent infection, bladder stones).  Many men with mild symptoms can be managed conservatively with lifestyle changes alone.  More severe cases may require medication or surgery.  Commonly used treatment modalities include the following:

Behavioral modifications 



Useful strategies include: shifting fluid intake to earlier in the day, decreasing caffeine and alcohol intake, and having scheduled and/or double voiding to ensure complete bladder emptying.

Medications



  • Alpha-adrenergic antagonists:  These antagonists are usually the first-line therapy.  They relax smooth muscle in the bladder neck, prostate capsule, and prostatic urethra.  Adverse effects include dizziness and orthostatic hypotension.  Nonuroselective drugs (eg, doxazosin, prazosin) also affect vascular smooth muscle and can lower blood pressure; uroselective drugs (eg, tamsulosin, alfuzosin) have less effect on blood pressure.
  • 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (eg, finasteride, dutasteride):  These medications inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT.  They gradually reduce prostate size and vascularity (ie, they can reduce hematuria).  The effect is slow (6-12 months).  Adverse effects include decreased libido and erectile dysfunction.  These inhibitors are usually used as second line but may be added to alpha blockers.
  • Tadalafil:  Daily low-dose tadalafil can reduce BPH symptoms.  Often used in patients with comorbid erectile dysfunction.

Surgical (invasive) treatment 



Surgical options include transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) (

figure 4
), laser enucleation of the prostate, and transurethral microwave thermotherapy.

Complications



Complications in BPH can be caused by increased urinary hydrostatic pressure, maladaptive urodynamic compensation, and urine stasis (

figure 5
).  Notable complications include the following:



  • Acute urinary retention:  Acute urine retention can occur spontaneously or due to anticholinergic medications (eg, first-generation antihistamines [eg, diphenhydramine], cyclic antidepressants [eg, amitriptyline]), which depress detrusor muscle contractions.  Immediate drainage via urethral (or occasionally suprapubic) catheter may be required.
  • Chronic urinary retention and obstructive uropathy:  This combination can lead to hydroureter, hydronephrosis, and chronic kidney disease.  Renal ultrasonography may reveal cortical atrophy.
  • UTI:  UTIs are common in men with BPH.
  • Bladder stones:  BPH can increase the risk for bladder stones due to the persistence of urine in the bladder and recurrent bladder infection.
  • Dysfunctional voiding:  Manifestations of dysfunctional voiding include overflow incontinence and detrusor hypotonicity.
  • Erectile dysfunction:  Some medications used to treat BPH can cause erectile dysfunction.

Prognosis



Symptoms of BPH are typically persistent and often progressive, and untreated disease can lead to complications such as urinary retention and kidney damage.  Medical management is usually successful, but symptoms may progress despite treatment.  Surgical procedures can often alleviate symptoms refractory to medication, but obstruction due to hyperplasia of the remaining tissue may recur years later.

Summary



Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a common condition that affects men as they age.  It is characterized by enlargement of the prostate gland, which can lead to a variety of urinary symptoms.  Management depends on the severity of the symptoms and may include lifestyle changes, medications, or surgery.  With appropriate treatment, most men with BPH can manage their symptoms effectively.
